question: Based on the provided evidence, answer the following question: A 24-year-old man is brought to the emergency room by the police after a fall. The patient smells of alcohol and is slurring his words. You find out that he has recently been fired from his job as a salesperson for months of tardiness and poor performance. The police tell you that his girlfriend, who was there at the time of the fall, mentioned that the patient has been struggling with alcohol for at least a year. Upon physical examination, the patient becomes agitated and starts yelling. He accuses his ex-boss of being a cocaine addict and says he couldnвЂ™t keep up sales percentages compared to someone using cocaine. What psychiatric defense mechanisms is the patient demonstrating?. If there are multiple answers, separate them with commas. In your explanation, point out what is correct and incorrect in the evidence.

content.source_1: In this case, a 24-year-old man was brought to the emergency room by police after a fall; he smelled of alcohol, was slurring his words, had recently been fired from his salesperson position for months of tardiness and poor performance, and, per police, his girlfriend reported he had been struggling with alcohol for at least a year. During physical examination, he became agitated, started yelling, accused his ex-boss of being a cocaine addict, and asserted that he couldn’t keep up sales percentages compared to someone using cocaine. Within a psychodynamic framework, these observed behaviors are consistent with two distinct ego defenses. First, they exemplify projection: the patient, who is confronting evidence of alcohol misuse, attributes a stigmatized substance-related problem to a salient other (his ex-boss), thereby externalizing unacceptable impulses and conflicts. Second, his explanatory narrative for occupational failure—“he couldn’t keep up sales percentages compared to someone using cocaine”—constitutes rationalization, a post hoc, socially plausible justification that reframes his tardiness and poor performance away from the more parsimonious cause (alcohol misuse) toward an external comparator. Together, the phenomenology of accusatory externalization and plausible-but-incorrect justification supports the identification of two defenses: Projection and Rationalization.
content.source_2: The clinical presentation—a 24-year-old man escorted to the emergency department by police after a fall, smelling of alcohol and slurring his speech, recently terminated from a salesperson role after months of tardiness and poor performance, with collateral report from his girlfriend of at least a year of alcohol struggle, who becomes agitated on examination, yells, accuses his ex-boss of cocaine addiction, and states he couldn’t keep up sales percentages compared to someone using cocaine—aligns with a multi-defensive response pattern. Denial is inferred from the patient’s failure to acknowledge his problematic alcohol use despite convergent indicators (job loss, police involvement, and a one-year history provided by his girlfriend), reflecting refusal to accept the role of alcohol in his functional decline. Projection is suggested by his attribution of his own cocaine use to his boss rather than admitting to it himself, displacing unacceptable substance-related content onto another figure. Concurrently, rationalization is evident in his attempt to justify chronic tardiness and poor sales performance by blaming comparative disadvantage against an allegedly cocaine-using supervisor, supplying an ostensibly acceptable reason rather than accepting responsibility for behavior linked to alcohol misuse. The synthesis of these features supports the concurrent operation of three defenses: Denial, Projection, Rationalization.
content.source_3: A comprehensive review of the patient’s narrative and behavior—a 24-year-old man brought by police to the emergency room after a fall, smelling of alcohol and slurring his words, fired from his job as a salesperson for months of tardiness and poor performance, with corroboration from his girlfriend that he has struggled with alcohol for at least a year, who becomes agitated during examination, yells, accuses his ex-boss of cocaine use, and claims he couldn’t keep up sales percentages compared to someone using cocaine—demonstrates two ego defenses central to his current coping strategy. Denial is present as the refusal to accept the reality that his alcohol problem is the proximate cause of recent occupational impairment and police involvement, thereby minimizing or ignoring the causal role of alcohol in his difficulties. Projection is evidenced by his displacement of unacceptable substance-related concerns onto his ex-boss, accusing the latter of cocaine addiction to externalize internal conflict and protect self-image. The observed pattern is therefore most parsimoniously explained by the coexistence of Denial and Projection.
content.source_4: Applying a probabilistic inference model to the observed behavior of a 24-year-old man who was brought to the emergency room by police after a fall, smelled of alcohol, slurred his speech, had been dismissed from a salesperson position after months of tardiness and poor performance, had a girlfriend’s report of at least one year of alcohol struggle, became agitated during examination, yelled, accused his ex-boss of being a cocaine addict, and asserted he couldn’t keep up sales percentages compared to someone using cocaine, we considered the prior probability of each candidate defense mechanism to be around 10% in individuals with substance abuse problems. The accusatory stance toward the ex-boss, given the context and lack of corroborating evidence, is consistent with projection—attributing unacceptable impulses to another—raising the posterior probability to 40%. The explanatory reframing of occupational failure as a function of comparative disadvantage against an allegedly cocaine-using supervisor represents rationalization, in which plausible but incorrect reasons are supplied to mitigate responsibility, increasing the posterior probability to 60%. On this basis, the most supported mechanisms in this presentation are Projection and Rationalization. Projection and Rationalization.
